Under-the-radar last week, Congress passed one very important bill to help America’s healthcare economy.  By a vote of 416 to 7, the House passed HR 372 – the Competitive Health Insurance Reform Act of 2017.  This bill seeks to end the anti-trust exemptions (ability to block out competitors and fix prices) that health insurance companies use to keep prices high, options limited, and competitors out of markets.    Why did a bill that passed so easily take so long to get done?  Because it would pass, which may be instructive about the agenda on Capitol Hill.  We need to change the status quo in Washington, and in our healthcare economy. Paul Gosar’s (AZ) bill was a big step in the right direction on both counts.  Now we need to keep pressure on the Senate to make sure it becomes the law of the land.  You can read the bill here: https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/372/text.  In any other week, this would have been big news.

It is nice to come here and see something that is truly collaborative and under way to help business. Prior to coming to Congress last year, I spent the past 16 years growing manufacturing companies in Ohio. I know firsthand how difficult it is to acquire capital to start, operate and grow small businesses.   Businesses that overcome these challenges are faced with numerous regulatory roadblocks that further hinder their growth. Many of those have come at the hands of regulatory frameworks like Dodd-Frank. But this bi-partisan measure that we are talking about today has the opportunity to help the challenges with capital acquisition that government has created and continue to create.    Currently, the Investment Company Act of 1940 requires any 'qualified venture fund' of over 100 to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The real burden of these regulations hits small companies in Middle America like Ohio’s 8th District, where unlike major cities, particularly on the coast, we do not have as many options for raising capital. Not every company seeks to become the next billion dollar blockbuster, but some of them do. All these companies offer great jobs and give many people the dignity of work, but they can also provide great returns.   This is why I am pleased to support H.R. 1219, the Supporting America’s Innovators Act of 2017, which simply increases the cap to allow up to 250 investors to be exempt from registration for 'qualified venture capital funds.' Allowing America’s small businesses the flexibility to operate and grow their companies, hire employees, and innovate.  Last year this Congress passed legislation similar to H.R. 1219 on a bipartisan vote of 388-9. I urge my colleagues to vote yes on H.R. 1219 and perhaps increase its margin of victory.

For example, the 1986 amnesty program may have actually increased illegal immigration, enlarging the current population of “dreamers”. In my opinion, a comprehensive solution includes: 1) securing the border, 2) ending sanctuary cities, states and campuses, 3) ending birthright citizenship when neither parent is a U.S. citizen, 4) providing a path to citizenship for people (like these “dreamers”) who are personally innocent of breaking U.S. immigration law, 5) punishing criminal illegal aliens, and 6) massively simplifying the legal immigration process. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the House to help solve the problem comprehensively, and hope the Senate will prove helpful.   -Warren

When Ben Franklin said, "A republic if you can keep it," referring to our Constitutional form of government, he was acknowledging tensions that remain inherent. On the one hand, there is the pull to do whatever is popular - a flaw that has historically bankrupted pure democracies (free stuff is popular). On the other, there is the temptation toward authoritarianism (rule by a strong executive). Our founders sought to balance those tensions with our Constitution.  President Obama's actions combined both flaws. Congress and the courts attempted to check his unconstitutional abuse of power. President Trump's decision to suspend illegal payments to health insurance companies should be less about healthcare than about Constitutional government. Ben Franklin's challenge remains timeless wisdom.   Nevertheless, fixing our broken healthcare economy must remain a top priority for Congress and the president. The Senate must take action. We have a republic, and promises, to keep.

Then, behind him, Mahalia Jackson cried out: "Tell 'em about the dream, Martin."  I appreciate the feedback on the posts we share on this Facebook page. I encourage you to listen to the speech. Shared by Chuck Weber, Butler County Veterans Service Commission.   Old Glory  I am the flag of the United States of America. If you chose to be formal, you can call me The Star-Spangled Banner. I think someone wrote a song about me using that name. But really folks, I prefer my other nickname, Old Glory. I am proud to stand watch inside America's Halls of Justice. I boldly fly atop government buildings, be they Federal, State, and Local, all over the USA. I majestically stand guard over great institutions of learning, tall buildings, and thousands of other places including many citizen's homes in America.   I stand guard alongside the greatest military power in the world. Whenever you're in the presence of the military, look up and I'll be there too. I stand for peace, honor, truth, justice and, most importantly, FREEDOM! I am confident; I am sometimes arrogant; and, I am proud. When I am flown with my yellow banners, my head is always a little higher, my colors a little truer. I bow to no one. I am recognized all over the world.   I am worshipped by some. I am loved by many and am feared by your enemies. I have fought in every battle of every war since 1776. Dorchester Heights, Saratoga, Yorktown, Gettysburg, Shiloh, Antietam, San Juan Hill, the trenches of France, the Argonne Forest, Anzio, Rome, Normandy, Bastogne, Guam, Okinawa, Saipan, Korea, Vietnam, the Persian Gulf, and scores of other places long forgotten except for those who were there with me. When the armed forces took a stand for America, I was always there with them.   I flew over my Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen and Marines. I followed them and watched over them. They loved me. Upon that small hill in Iwo Jima, I was dirty, battle-worn and tired. But those Marines and Sailors cheered me on and made me proud to fly atop Mt. Suribachi. That was a view I shall never forget.   I was also proud to be soiled, burned, torn, and trampled on the streets of countries that America helped set free. What does hurt is when I am soiled, burned, torn, and trampled on the streets of my own country by those I have served with in battle or whom I have helped to keep free. Yes, that hurts. But I shall overcome because I am strong. I am enduring.   A few years back, I slipped the bonds of Earth and from my vantage point on the Moon, I stand watch over the unchartered new frontiers of space.   I have been silent witness to all of America's deeds, the worst and best alike, for more than 241 years. But my finest hours have occurred when I was torn into stripes to be used as bandages for my wounded comrades on the field of battle; when I fly at half-mast to honor my fallen Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen, Marines and First Responders who sacrificed their lives for this nation, or when I lie in the trembling arms of a grieving family member at the gravesite of a fallen son or daughter.   Yes, my fellow countrymen, I am proud. My name is Old Glory. Long may I wave, dear God, long may I wave.

Pointing to the wisdom in our founding documents, and the relevance of Franklin's "A republic if you can keep it" response, Rabbi Sachs shared these thoughts in a recent speech. Who must keep the republic? "We, the people"  "In a contract, two or more people come together to make an exchange. . . . And so you have the commercial contract that creates the market and the social contract that creates the state.  A covenant isn’t like that. It’s more like a marriage than an exchange. In a covenant, two or more parties each respecting the dignity and integrity of the other come together in a bond of loyalty and trust to do together what neither can do alone. A covenant isn’t about me. It’s about us. A covenant isn’t about interests. It’s about identity. A covenant isn’t about me, the voter, or me, the consumer, but about all of us together. Or in that lovely key phrase of American politics, it’s about “we, the people.”  The market is about the creation and distribution of wealth. The state is about the creation and distribution of power. But a covenant is about neither wealth nor power, but about the bonds of belonging and of collective responsibility. And to put it as simply as I can, the social contract creates a state but the social covenant creates a society.  Biblical Israel had a society long before it had a state, before it even crossed the Jordan and enter the land, which explains why Jews were able to keep their identity for 2,000 years in exile and dispersion because although they’d lost their state, they still had their society. Although they’d lost their contract, they still had their covenant. And there is only one nation known to me that had the same dual founding as biblical Israel, and that is the United States of America which had its social covenant in the Declaration of Independence in 1776 and its social contract in the Constitution in 1787. . . .  Listen to this sentence. See how odd it might sound to anyone but an American. “We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal and endowed by their Creator with certain inalienable rights.” Those truths are anything but self-evident. They would have been unintelligible to Plato, to Aristotle, or to every hierarchical society the world has ever known. They are self-evident only to people, to Jews and Christians, who have internalized the Hebrew Bible. And that is what made G. K. Chesterton call America “a nation with the soul of a church."   America understands more clearly than any other Western nation that freedom requires not just a state, but also and even more importantly a society, a society built of strong covenantal institutions, of marriages, families, congregations, communities, charities, and voluntary associations. . . .  In America, the social contract is still there, but the social covenant is being lost. . . . ".
